text.wiki:
Antibes (, also US: , French: [ɑ̃tib] (listen); Provençal: Antíbol) is a coastal city in the Alpes-Maritimes department of southeastern France, on the Côte d'Azur between Cannes and Nice.
The town of Juan-les-Pins is in the commune of Antibes and the Sophia Antipolis technology park is northwest of it.


== History ==


=== Origins ===
Traces of occupation dating back to the early Iron Age have been found in the areas of the castle and cathedral. Remains beneath the Holy Spirit Chapel show there was an indigenous community with ties with Mediterranean populations, including the Etruscans, as evidenced by the presence of numerous underwater amphorae and wrecks off Antibes. However, most trade was with the Greek world, via the Phocaeans of Marseille.


=== Colony of Marseille ===
Antibes was founded by Phocaeans from Massilia. 
As a Greek colony (and later Roman) settlement, it was named Antipolis (Greek: Ἀντίπολις, Antípolis, lit. "Cross-City") from its position close to Nice (anc. Νίκαια - Nikaia).
Current research suggests that Antipolis was founded relatively late (4th century BC), to benefit from the protection of Marseille with its trade routes along the coast and strongholds like Olbia at Hyères, and trading posts such as Antipolis itself and later Nikaia; it is mentioned by Strabo.The exact location of the Greek city is not well known. Given Greek colonial practices, it is likely that it was set at the foot of the rock of Antibes, in today's old city. Traces of occupation in the Hellenistic period have been identified around the castle and the church (former cathedral). The goods unearthed during these excavations show the dominance of imported products of the Marseilles region, associated with Campanian and indigenous ceramics.
Early in the second century BC the Ligurian Deceates and Oxybiens tribes launched repeated attacks against Nikaia and Antipolis. The Greeks of Marseille appealed to Rome as they had already done a few years earlier against the federation of Salyens. In 154 BC the consul Quintus Opimius defeated the Décéates and Oxybiens and took Aegythna from the Décéates.


=== Roman Antipolis ===
Rome gradually increased its hold over the Mediterranean coast. In 43 BC, Antipolis was officially incorporated in the propraetorial (senatorial from 27 BC) province of Narbonesian Gaul, in which it remained for the next 500 years. Antipolis grew into the largest town in the region and a main entry point into Gaul. Roman artifacts such as aqueducts, fortified walls, and amphoræ can still be seen today.


==== Aqueducts ====

The city was supplied with water by two aqueducts.
The Fontvieille aqueduct rises in Biot, and eventually joins the coast below the RN7 and the railway track at the Fort Carré. It was rediscovered and restored in the 18th century by the Chevalier d'Aguillon to supply the modern city.
The aqueduct called the Bouillide or Clausonnes rises near the town of Valbonne. Monumental remains of aqueduct bridges are located in the neighbourhood of Fugaret, in the forest of Valmasque and near the town of Vallauris.


==== Theatre and amphitheatre ====
Like most Roman towns, Antipolis possessed buildings for shows and entertainment. A Roman theatre is attested by the tombstone of the child "Septentrion". The inscription says "he danced and was popular on the stage of the theatre". The theatre was located, like the amphitheatre, between Rue de la République and Rue de Fersen, near the Porte Royale. The back wall is positioned substantially next to Rue Fourmillère. A radial wall was found on the right side of the bus station. A plan of the theatre made in the 16th century is in the Marciana National Library of Venice.
The remains of the amphitheatre were still visible at the end of the 17th century during the restructuring of the fortifications of the city. A concentric oval was still visible in many plans of the seventeenth century and in a map of Antibes from the early nineteenth century. These remains are now covered by the Fersen middle school.


==== Town houses or villas ====
Excavations in the old town have discovered well-preserved houses showing some luxury. Among them, the most monumental are those in the rectory garden of rue Clemenceau. These show a comparable level to that of the Gallo-Roman domus such as those of Saint-Romain-en-Gal. Large parts of the floor mosaic are organised around a courtyard with a marble fountain. The building dates from the late third century, although parts date from the end of the Hellenistic era or the end of the Roman Republic. Another house paved with porphyry and green stone was excavated between rue des Palmiers and the rue de la Blancherie. The finds at the Antibes Museum of Archaeology suggests the main occupation between the 2nd and 4th century. Finds from the end of the Hellenistic era and the end of the Roman Republic is present on both sites.


=== Antipolis in late antiquity ===
Antipolis became the seat of a bishopric in the 5th century. After the disintegration of the Western Roman Empire, various barbarian tribes seized Antibes. This resulted in destruction and a long period of instability. In the 10th century Antibes found a protector in Seigneur Rodoart, who built extensive fortified walls around the town and a castle in which to live. For the next 200 years, the town experienced a period of renewal. Prosperity was short-lived, for the whole region fell into disarray for several centuries. The inhabitants of Antibes stayed behind their strong city walls as a succession of wars and epidemics ravaged the countryside. In 1244, Antibes's bishop moved his see to Grasse. By the end of the 15th century, the region was under the protection and control of King Louis XI of France. Relative stability returned, but the small port of Antibes fell into obscurity.


== Modern era ==

From around the middle of the 19th century the Antibes area regained its popularity, as wealthy people from around Europe discovered its natural environment and built luxurious homes there. It was transferred from its former department of Var to the new one of Alpes Maritimes in 1860. The harbor was again used for a "considerable" fishing industry and the area exported dried fruit, salt fish, and oil.By the First World War, it had been connected by rail with Nice and most of its fortifications had been demolished to make way for new residential districts. In 1926, the old Château Grimaldi in Antibes was bought by the local municipality and later restored for use as a museum. Pablo Picasso came to the town in 1946, having visited his friend and fellow painter Gerald Murphy and his wife Sara there in 1923, and was invited to stay in the castle. During his six-month stay, Picasso painted and drew, as well as crafting ceramics and tapestries. When he departed, Picasso left a number of his works to the municipality. The castle has since become the Picasso Museum.


== Culture ==


=== Conservation ===
On 25 May 1999, the town was the first in the départment to sign the State Environment Charter, which pledges to actively conserve the natural environment.


=== Sports ===
Sport is an important part of the local culture; the town hosts the National Training Centre for basketball. The Jean Bunoz Sports Hall hosted several games of the FIBA EuroBasket 1999. The city is home to Olympique Antibes, a professional basketball team of France's top division LNB Pro A, which plays its home games at the Azur Arena Antibes.


=== Music ===
There is a jazz festival, Jazz à Juan, in July.


== Population ==


== Politics ==


=== Presidential Elections 2nd Round ===


== Sights ==


=== Beaches ===

There are 48 beaches along the 25 km (16 miles) of coastline that surround Antibes and Juan les Pins.


=== Museums ===
Archaeology Museum
This museum sits atop the Promenade Amiral de Grasse in the old Bastion St Andre, a 17th-century fortress. The museum's collection focuses on the classical history of Antibes. Many artifacts, sculptures and amphorae found in local digs and shipwrecks from the harbour are displayed here.
Naval Museum of Napoleon
Housed in a 17th-century stone fort and tower, this museum presents a collection of Napoleonic memorabilia, paintings and naval models. Several wall paintings show historic moments in Napoleon's reign and there are also pieces of his clothing including one of the hats he wore.
Picasso Museum
This museum houses one of the world's greatest Picasso collections: 24 paintings, 44 drawings, 32 lithographs, 11 oils on paper, 80 pieces of ceramics, two sculptures and five tapestries.
La Tour Museum
This small museum in the centre of town brings the contemporary history of Antibes to life through its exhibit of costumes, tools, photographs and other objects used by the local people.
Absinthe Museum
The Absinthe Museum is located in a basement in the Roman foundations of Old Antibes. It is dedicated to the manufacture and appreciation of this green liqueur.


=== Parks and gardens ===
The Exflora Park
The Exflora Park is a five-hectare (12 acres) garden open to the public. Next to the large olive grove, there are different styles of Mediterranean gardens, from ancient Rome to the exuberant Riviera of the 19th century. Fountains and ponds stretch along the terrace, making a waterway 500 metres (1,600 ft) long. Antibes is renowned for rose production, and rose bushes line the path leading to the sea. The exotic garden and palm grove is reminiscent of the belle époque, when English gardeners succeeded in planting flowers that bloom in winter, the season when the aristocracy visited the Côte d'Azur.
A little further on is the Théâtre de Verdure, inspired by Italian gardens, and a panoramic viewpoint with a view of the sea and the Iles des Lerins. In the style of Provençal gardens of the 18th century, there is a maze with sculpted hedges. Further on, Islamic gardens are featured, with an orange grove where the ground is patterned with terracotta irrigation pipes similar to those in the celebrated Seville Cathedral in Spain. The vegetable gardens and orchards in the Arsat are planted in hollows as in Morocco to protect them from the sun and maximise shadow and humidity. A representation of a Moroccan house pays homage to the painter Majorelle, creator of the blue garden in Marrakesh. In another area, the winter garden contains plants that flower in winter, such as mimosa and camellias.
The Eilenroc Gardens
Villa Eilenroc was built on a rock in the middle of a virtual desert. The area was transformed into a garden through the patience and talent of Jacques Greber, landscape architect and consultant to the Great Exhibition in New York City in 1939. He was commissioned by Mr Beaumont to create this park of 11 hectares (27 acres).
The gardens lie thirty metres above the sea with a view across the bay of the Cap. Planted with traditional Mediterranean species such as marine and parasol pines, Alep and Canary pines, cypress, oaks, olive trees, arbutus, lavender, thyme, rosemary, eucalyptus, ficus etc., as well as three kilometres (1.9 miles) of pittosporum hedges, a whole part of the park has been created with plants found in the Antibes area in 1920.
Thuret Park
In 1857, Gustave Thuret discovered the Cap d'Antibes and bought five hectares (12 acres) of land where he built a villa and began the creation of a park. Bequeathed to the state by his heirs, the Jardin botanique de la Villa Thuret is now managed by the INRA (National Institute of Agronomic Research). The collection of trees and exotic plants, and the rich earth, provide many opportunities for learning, and the cross-fertilisation of plant species that grow on the Mediterranean coast.
Marineland
In 1970, Roland de la Poype created this animal exhibition park in Antibes. First, it was a small oceanarium with a few pools and animals, but now it is one of the biggest in the world and receives more than 1,200,000 visitors per year. It is the only French sea park featuring two cetacean species: killer whales and dolphins.


=== Garoupe Lighthouse ===

The old lighthouse of Antibes provides views from its lofty hilltop. To get here, you must walk about one kilometre up the Chemin de Calvaire from the Plage de la Salis. It makes for a nice half-day stroll.


=== Church of the Immaculate Conception ===

The central church in Antibes was first built in the 11th century with stones used from earlier Roman structures. Its current façade was constructed in the 18th century and blends Latin classical symmetry and religious fantasy. The interior houses some impressive pieces such as a Baroque altarpiece and life-sized wooden carving of Christ's death from 1447.


=== Hôtel du Cap-Eden Roc ===
This villa, set in "a forest" at the tip of the Cap d'Antibes peninsula, re-creates a nineteenth-century château. Since 1870 the glamorous white-walled Hotel du Cap on the French Riviera has been one of the most storied and luxurious resorts in the world. Guests who flocked there included Marlene Dietrich, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor and Winston Churchill. Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton conducted an affair and honeymooned there.


=== Ports ===

There are many yachting harbours which provide moorings for a range of ships ranging from fishing vessels to full sized yachts.

Port Vauban: The largest yachting harbour in Europe, with more than 2,000 moorings, can accommodate craft of more than 100 metres. This old port was the heart of the ancient Greek city of Antipolis and has a long and colourful history which includes Ligurians, Romans and Crusaders on their way to the Holy Land. Today, it is the largest marina in Europe, serving both local fishing boats and luxury yachts.
Port Galice: 542 moorings
Port de la Salis: 233 moorings
Port du Croûton: 390 moorings
Port de l'Olivette: Situated in the sheltered cove of the same name, this is a harbour for sailors and their wooden fishing boats who enjoy the old marine, provencal traditions.


=== Theatre and music ===
The Théâtre Antibea, Théâtre des Heures Bleues and Café Théâtre la Scène sur Mer all offer a variety of performances from orchestra music to dramatic plays. Music of all types, from live jazz to DJs spinning techno, can be found in the bars and nightclubs and there are a number of festivals and special outdoor concerts during the summer. Jazz is still the speciality around here, and the Juan les Pins Jazz Festival is one of the best in the world.M83 (an electronic band) hails from Antibes.


=== Festivals ===

Antibes and Juan les Pins host a number of festivals, mainly during the summer months. There's not much in the way of traditional cultural festivals in Antibes; most of the festivals focus on music and contemporary activities.

Jazz à Juan remains one of the top jazz festivals in the world. Since its inception in 1960, it has attracted many Jazz artists each year to play outdoors. (July).
Antibes Yacht Show
The Antique Show of Antibes attracts thousands of collectors for two weeks in April. It's one of the largest shows of its kind in France (April).
Voiles d'Antibes is one of the world's biggest gatherings of old teak and brass sailing vessels. They converge on the port for one of the most regal regattas in the Mediterranean (June).
The Festival of Saint Peter is the annual celebration of the patron saint of fishermen. A colourful procession through the town is followed by all the local fishermen adorning their boats and floating along the coast (June).
The Festival of Sacred Music takes place in Antibes Cathedral, which has renowned acoustics. Sacred music is the theme of this popular festival, which attracts huge crowds each year (January).


== Climate ==
Antibes enjoys a Mediterranean climate.


== Shopping ==
Marché Provençal


== Transport ==
The Gare d'Antibes is the railway station serving the town, offering connections to Nice, Cannes, Marseille, Grasse, St Raphael, Les Arcs, Milan, Ventimiliga, Paris and several other destinations. This railway station is in the centre of town. There is another railway station, Juan les Pins. The nearest airport is Nice Côte d'Azur Airport and Cannes Airport.


== Personalities ==
Mike Cumberlege, Royal Navy officer
Ignazio Dracopoli, Anglo–French cartographer and explorer
Flocke and Rasputin (aka Flocon et Rasputine), polar bears living at Marineland
Graham Greene lived in a small apartment in Antibes in his later years
Gloria Guinness then Princess Fakhry married Thomas "Loel" Guinness in April 1951
Nikos Kazantzakis, writer of the novel Zorba the Greek, owned a villa in Old Town
M83, electronic artist
Ruth Madoff (born 1941), wife of Bernie Madoff
Gerald and Sara Murphy, wealthy Americans credited with establishing the French Riviera as a summer resort
Guillaume Musso, writer
Pablo Picasso, painter
Gabriel Guevrekian, architect
Halima Soussi, basketball player
Nicolas de Staël, painter
Luc-Arthur Vebobe, basketball player
Duke of Windsor, Aristotle Onassis and Stavros Niarchos, at different times, lived in Château de la Croë
Nikola I Petrović-Njegoš (1841-1921), died in Antibes

sights.name: Museum of Classical Art in Mougins

text.wiki:
The MACM, the Mougins Museum of Classical Art (Musée d’Art Classique de Mougins) is an art museum located in the village of Mougins, in the Alpes-Maritimes region of France. It is 30 minutes from Nice airport and 15 minutes from the centre of Cannes.
The MACM opened to the public in June 2011. The museum has won several international awards and has loaned dozens of objects to other museums and university exhibitions all over the world.
The museum’s large and diverse collection of antiquities includes Roman, Greek and Egyptian sculpture, vases, coins, and jewellery, and the world’s largest private collection of ancient arms and armour .
The ancient artworks are interspersed with paintings, drawings, and sculptures by artists such as Henri Matisse, Marc Chagall, Raoul Dufy, Paul Cézanne, Auguste Rodin, Salvador Dalí, Andy Warhol, Marc Quinn, Antony Gormley, and Damien Hirst, and others. The collection also includes works by artists who spent time in Mougins, such as Francis Picabia, Jean Cocteau, Man Ray, and Pablo Picasso (who spent the final 12 years of his life in Mougins village).
The founder of the museum is Christian Levett, a British investment manager with an interest in history and art. A collector since childhood, in 2009 he formed the museum to place his antiquity and classical art collection on public display. The Musée de Mougins was created by remodelling a 600m2 medieval edifice to house his collection. The building itself used to be the village prison in medieval times, it was then turned into a mill before becoming a private residence in the 1950s.  The interior was entirely renovated to display the collection while the façade remains in its original style.
The museum’s director is Leisa Paoli.


== Concept ==
Although the majority of objects on display are antiquities, the museum embraces a concept of displaying ancient, neo-classical, modern and contemporary art side by side to show the pervasive and lasting influence of the ancient world. Thus works by Sir Peter Paul Rubens, Marc Chagall, Henri Matisse, Damien Hirst and others are included in the museum alongside their ancient inspirations.
This dialogue and fusion between ancient and modern is particularly clear in the museum where, for example, depictions of the Greek Goddess Aphrodite by Warhol, Dalí and Yves Klein accompany 1st and 2nd Century AD depictions of the Goddess, in marble and in bronze.


== History ==
Founder, Christian Levett, a philanthropist in the field, sponsored multiple exhibitions at The British Museum, Royal Academy, National Gallery, Sir John Soane’s Museum and the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford. He has funded archaeological works in the UK, Spain, Italy and Egypt and sponsored academic scholarships at Wolfson College and The Ruskin School of Art in Oxford. He has aided curatorial funding at The Ashmolean, The British Museum, and The British School at Rome.
As well as this, he has funded renovation works at The Charterhouse Museum London, Charterhouse School Surrey, The National Gallery and the chapel Notre Dame de Vie in Mougins, and has sponsored conferences at King’s College London, Senate House UCL and at The Mougins Museum. He is a member of the Arms and Armour Committee at The Metropolitan Museum of New York and member of The Board of Visitors at The Ashmolean Museum Oxford and is a past board member of The Hadrian’s Wall Trust. Levett is also an Honorary Fellow of The Ashmolean Museum, an honorary fellow of Wolfson College Oxford and a member of the Oxford University Chancellors Court of Benefactors.
On 29 October 2019 Levett consigned for sale at Christie's a marble statue of the Emperor Hadrian from his collection, known as the Cobham Hall Hadrian, to benefit the Museum.


== Collection ==
The MACM is spread over four floors chronologically from the crypt to the second floor as follows: The Egyptian Gallery, in the crypt, depicts the theme of the afterlife with funerary masks, numerous other ancient artefacts and a sarcophagus, punctuated with works from Chagall, Calder, Rubens and Cocteau. The People and Personalities Gallery on the ground floor presents busts and statues of historical figures from ancient Greece and Rome, their influence highlighted by sculptures of Sosno, Arman, Quinn and Hirst. The Gods and Goddesses Gallery, on the first floor, displays Greek and Roman bronze and marble statues, heads and busts, pottery, glass and silverware, an extensive collection of coins and an antique jewellery display case. Works by neo-classical and modern artists such as Renoir, Rodin, Klein, Warhol, Picasso, Modigliani, Braque and Dalí are also exhibited in the museum. The Armoury, on the second floor, displays the largest private collection of Greek and Roman arms and armour in the world.
		
		


== Publications ==
The MACM has produced several publications, including:

Mougins Museum of Classical Art, 2011, edited by M. Merrony
La Collection Famille Levett, 2012, edited by M. Merrony and translated by C. Dauphin
Animals in the Ancient World, 2014, C. Dauphin
Pompeii in Pictures, 2015, K. Schörle
Les Animaux dans le Monde Antique, 2016, C. Dauphin
Dufy Dessine le Sud, 2019, F. Guillon Laffaille


== Exhibitions ==
The permanent collection at the MACM is constantly evolving. New pieces are acquired with a view to sustaining and developing the museum’s concept of the fusion of ancient and modern art and the influence that Antiquity has had on subsequent artistic creation.
The Museum has also hosted and been otherwise involved in many temporary exhibitions:


== Exhibitions at the MACM ==
Doric, Sean Scully. 12 July - 29 September 2013
Vessels, Gary Komarin. 1 May – 29 June 2014
Layers of Time, Alexander Mihaylovich. 10 April - 14 June 2015
Pompeii in pictures, Giorgio Sommer. 19 June – 2 August 2015
Animal, The Levett Bestiary collection. February – June 2016
Past is present, Léo Caillard. 16 March – 27 May 2018
Bleu-Topique, Johan Van Mullem. 16 November 2018 – 17 March 2019
Dufy dessine le Sud (Dufy depicts the South), Raoul Dufy. 23 March - 1 September 2019


== 'Hors Les Murs' external exhibitions ==
Mythes et Héros (Myths and Heroes), 14 April – 28 May 2012A collaboration with the town of Mougins at the Espace Culturel de Mougins

Picasso à Mougins (Picasso in Mougins), 28 March – 12 May 2013A collaboration with the town of Mougins at the Espace Culturel de Mougins

Picasso at the Mas Candille, Lucien Clergue, 15 – 26 May 2013A collaboration with the 5* Relais & Chateaux hotel Le Mas Candille at Le Mas Candille, Mougins

Sacha Sosno. Un hommage, 8 May – 15 June 2014A collaboration with the town of Mougins at the Espace Culturel de Mougins

Mougins Monumental 2015, 4 April – 30 August 2015A collaboration with the town of Mougins - open air exhibition in Mougins Village

Ici et maintenant (Here and now), 15 September – 31 December 2016A collaboration between the FRAC, the town of Mougins, and the association MVE (Mougins Village Energy).

Mougins Monumental 2016, 5 March – 29 May 2016A collaboration with the town of Mougins - open air exhibition in Mougins Village

The Classical Now, 2 March – 28 April 2018A collaboration with King’s College of London at The Arcade at Bush House & The Inigo Rooms, Somerset House East Wing King’s College London, UK


== Loans ==
The MACM's important loan programme has seen numerous artefacts and artworks on loan to the following establishments:

Braunschweigisches Landesmuseum, Brunswick, Germany
British Museum, London, UK
Espace d’Art Concret, Mouans Sartoux, France
Estorick Collection of Modern Italian Art, London, UK
Fondation Pierre-Gianadda, Martigny, Switzerland
Fondazione Prada, Venice, Italy
Kellos Gallery, London, UK
King's College London, London, UK
Musée d’Archéologie Méditerranéenne, La Vieille Charité, Marseille, France
Musée d’Archéologie de Nice, France
Musée Massena, Nice, France
Musée National du Sport, Nice, France
Musée National Marc Chagall, Nice, France
Musée Regards de Provence, Marseille, France
Musée Saint-Raymond, Toulouse, France
Römisch-Germanisches Museum, Cologne, Germany
Royal Academy of Arts, London, UK
Sao Paulo Museum of Modern Art (MASP), São Paulo, Brazil
Segedunum Roman Fort, Wallsend, UK
Sir John Soane’s Museum, London, UK
The J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles, USA
The Jewish Museum, New York, USA
Tullie House Museum & Art Gallery, Carlisle, UK
Vindolanda Trust Fort and Museum, Hexham, UK
The Wallace Collection, London, UK
Walters Art Museum, Baltimore, USA


== Prizes and accolades ==
Winner of the Apollo’s Museum Opening of the Year award in 2011.
Winner of the Nouveau Tourisme Culturel award Ken d’Or 2012.
Nominated for the European Museum of the Year award 2013
Nominated in the Virtual Reality/Augmented Reality category at the CLIC Patrimoine and Innovation(s) 2017 awards.
TripAdvisor’s Certificates of Excellence in 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018
Obtained the government-approved brand ‘Quality Tourism’ in 2016.


== References ==

2. "L'Antiquité au goût du jour", Connaissance des Arts, July–August 2012
3. "J’ai fait un rêve…", Zibeline Magazine, June 2012 
4. "The Acquisitive Gene", Apollo Magazine, 1 February 2012 
5. "The French Collection", The Financial Times, 30 December 2011
6. "Museum opening of the Year Apollo Magazine", Apollo Magazine, 1 December 2011

text.wiki:
Les Femmes d'Alger ("Women of Algiers") is a series of 15 paintings and numerous drawings by the Spanish artist Pablo Picasso. The series, created in 1954–1955, was inspired by Eugène Delacroix's 1834 painting The Women of Algiers in their Apartment (French: Femmes d'Alger dans leur appartement). The series is one of several painted by Picasso in tribute to artists that he admired.The entire series of Les Femmes d'Alger was bought by Victor and Sally Ganz from the Galerie Louise Leiris in Paris for $212,500 in June 1956 (equivalent to $2 million in 2019). Ten paintings from the series were later sold by the Ganz's to the Saidenberg Gallery, with the couple keeping versions "C", "H", "K", "M" and "O".Many of the individual paintings in the series are now in prominent public and private collections.


== Origin ==

In December 1954, Picasso began to paint a series of free variations on Delacroix's The Women of Algiers in their Apartment (Les Femmes d'Alger). He began his first version (cat. 19) six weeks after learning of the death of his lifelong friend and rival Henri Matisse—and so, for Picasso, the "oriental" subject of this series of paintings held strong associations with Matisse as well as with Delacroix. Matisse had been famous for his images of languid, voluptuous women known as odalisques—the French form of the Turkish word for women in a harem. "When Matisse died he left his odalisques to me as a legacy," joked Picasso. Many of Picasso's portrayals of Jacqueline circa 1955–56 represent her in this guise (cat. 9).The consequences of Picasso's Femmes d'Alger series were far-reaching: "I thought so much about Les Femmes d'Alger that I bought La Californie," Picasso explained to his biographer Pierre Daix. La Californie is a Belle Époque villa situated in the foothills of Cannes in the South of France, where Picasso spent his last decades. Picasso bought it in 1955, and it was here that he painted the Nude in a Rocking-Chair (cat. 16). The light-filled interiors, the views over the Mediterranean and the exotic garden evoked a feeling of spaciousness and ease which corresponded to Picasso's idea of the Orient.The art historian and collector Douglas Cooper was perhaps the first to realise that the paintings done at La Californie marked a return to Picasso's peak form. In April 1956, he wrote to the curator Alfred H. Barr Jr.:

I recently spent the day with Picasso and went through most of what he has done since last July. I have been greatly impressed...A whole series of interiors of La Californie deriving half from Delacroix half from Matisse—great emphasis on ornament, arabesque, simplification...In short, as you are planning to come to Europe, this is a word to tell you that you must see all this in the studio: it is to my mind much better than anything since 1946.


== List of notable works ==


=== "Version C" ===
"Version C" was sold in 1988 following Victor Ganz's death.


=== "Version F' ===
"Version F" was completed on 17 February 1955, and later sold to Daniel and Eleanore Saidenberg of the Saidenberg Gallery in 1957. It was subsequently sold to a private collector in 2011. The painting later was sold for $29.22 million on 10 July 2020, as part of the New York leg of the One: A Global Sale of the 20th Century auction of Christie's.


=== "Version H" ===
"Version H" was completed on 24 January 1955, and was in sold for $7.15 million in November 1997, as part of the Ganz collection, at Christie's in New York. It is part of the Nahmad Collection in Switzerland. In May 2015, it was on loan to Tate Liverpool, England.


=== "Version J" ===
"Version J" was sold at Sotheby's in London in 2006 for $18.6 million and is part of the Nahmad Collection.


=== "Version K" ===
"Version K" sold for $6.6 million in November 1997, as part of the Ganz collection, at Christie's in New York.


=== "Version L" ===
"Version L" was bought by the Berggruen Museum in Berlin in 2011 for $11.4 million.


=== "Version M" ===
"Version M" sold for $10 million in November 1997, as part of the Ganz collection, at Christie's in New York.


=== "Version N" ===
"Version N" is held by the Mildred Lane Kemper Art Museum at Washington University in St. Louis, and was bought by the Steinberg Fund, for the university, in 1960.


=== "Version O" ===
"Version O", the final painting in the series, was painted in 1955.The painting sold for $31.9 million in November 1997, as part of the Ganz collection, at Christie's in New York. Three other versions in the series owned by the Ganz family were also auctioned at the same time. "Version O" was bought, by the British art dealer Libby Howie, for an undisclosed Saudi Arabian collector living in London."Version O" was auctioned at Christie's New York for a second time in May 2015, and was expected to set a world record price for a work of art at auction. A pre-sale valuation of $140 million was placed by Christie's on the painting, one of the highest ever placed on an auctioned artwork. The most expensive work of art to previously sell at auction, Francis Bacon's painting Three Studies of Lucian Freud, had sold for $142.4 million against a pre-sale estimate of c.$85 million in 2013. An undisclosed reserve price had also been placed on the painting prior to the sale. The painting was sold for $179.4 million including fees, a record price for a painting at auction. It was bought by the former Qatari prime minister, Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani.

This museum holds a number of works by Picasso which are quite amazing. The museum is located in the centre of the city and has some spectacular views of the ocean. It does get packed so if you can, buy your tickets beforehand if you don't want to spend time queuing in the heat.
The museum itself is not worth going out of your way for..but just the city is worth visiting for a few hours... great scenic views and quaint little streets to stroll anout

A must if you go to Antibes. Loved the views from the terrace and great for photo taking. There are many works by other arts in the museum so start at the top floor if you want to get to the Picasso works. Loved learning about his life and lovers.
The museum is very interesting and has an amazing view! After a visit you can take a walk around and enjoy this lovely city! I felt in love with Antibes!!

We came to this museum as big admirers of Picasso's work, filled with hesitation to see what has he produced during his stay in Provence, We were surprised to see, that this museum holds not too many works of Picasso, most created in several months during hist stay at the

It was good to see. I mean, where else will you see so many of Pablo's works in one place? There were no audio guides so there was little context for the art we were viewing. The staff was put out. I left feeling a bit underwhelmed. I love art history and was disappointed

I have to admit although a fan of Art I am far from a fan of Picasso I think he is awful, BUT my girlfriend wanted to go and look round and because my family have had a place in Antibes for 20 years. So we went along and I have to say and my girlfriend agreed it was full of

Only 6€ each , you can leave your back pack for free with a minder, No photos allowed, I was surprised at the people taking photos After being told not too. Lovely display if other artists, quite dark work, great sketch selection of Picasso and some of his plates and pots. He
Before I visited the Picasso museum I did not really appreciate Picasso's work . I left feeling I understood it more. The location, by the sea adds atmosphere.

Amazing location right at cliffs edge, beautiful restored old building. Perfect lighting. Had small groupings of various contemporary French artists to fill out both the space and limited Picasso pieces. Much of Picasso related were sketches and photos. He was near Vallaruis

I found this museum by chance while i was walking around the Antibes town centre. The museum is located on top of hill so it has nice views. Some of paintings are Piccaso's but some of them are other painters'. If you like arts and paintings, worthwhile to visit. The enterance
Not as much about Picasso as you'd think but there were a lot of other nice pieces. The views of the sea are great - overlooks the bay towards the Cap D'Antibes.
Nice , but small museum. Besides the works of Picasso there are things other contemporary artists . Inside is forbidden to take photographs .

This museum is nice to visit when walking through the town. Picasso lived in Antibes and worked from this castle (that was previously owned by the Grimaldi's). We parked the car in the harbour, whoch is only a 5 minute walk
The location is amazing, as if all of a sudden you realize another world. The collection is also very interesting.

hadn't read up on what i was about to see here and was blown away - a fine selection of Picasso art - and many pieces new to me - have been to Picasso Museum in Cerat and seen all his ceramics - or so i though, so many here too - a great room of photos of the man at work too -

Very little Picasso, with two floors of other Antibes resident artists. Cool and spacious, but when another visitor used a camera, honestly the room security man shouted " I told you once, so I have to tell you in Japanese and Chinese as well, no photographs" which embarrassed
Beautiful building, well adapted as a gallery. Rooms add to experience . Staff were lovely apart from the unfriendly man at reception.
Excellent display of works with good story boards to accompany them. Reasonable €6 entry fee. Good for rainy day.

Weather made this visit a potential winner for the afternoon, however for the location and building the exhibits were not truly amazing. But learnt a bit and broadened the mind a little so no bad thing, not to busy as appears August stampede has calmed down, but not going have
Good selection of interesting pieces of art. Well laid out and easy to access. Very pleasant to wander around in the cool air when it is scorching outside.
The museum building is very atmospheric, situated on the sea front, and a perfect setting for the art work displayed. We visited with our 14year old daughter and all enjoyed the experience.

Not a bad thing to say about this museum. Stunning artwork of course and in a very special site in the charming old town of Antibes. The outside space overlooking the sea is breathtaking. Bronzes punctuate the wall above the sea. Worth a detour.
Small museum, but still good. We went on a Wednesday evening when it was open late (NB trip advisor has the late nights wrong - it's Wednesday and Friday). Great views from the terrace.
Magnificent pictures of the man at work and the most beautiful panorama of Antibes seaside Insights of the master of contemporary art

The museum sits over looking the Mediterranean coast in a stunning location. The building it's self has been kept to a very high standard and is air conditioned. There were several artist displaying their work in the museum and not just work done by Picasso when he was in

Set in what was Castle Grimaldi, the museum offers work by a selection of artists as well as a range of work by Picasso and an insight into his life and inspiration. The setting is superb, an impressive building looking out onto the sea with amazing views from many windows.

I had read mixed reviews on here but decided to see for myself.we visited on a Saturday afternoon.It was busy and we had to wait 20 mins in blaring heat to get in.there was no shade.when we did get in the ground floor and top floors were closed. I thought it was a really
It has a break at lunch. And is closing at 6. For the rest of it is a great museum. From the outdoord to everithing inside

Not the biggest museeum, but just about the right size you want to visit during the heat in summer Antibes. Intresting, and also works by other artist. Realy worth a visit if you are in the erea.

There are some interesting works of art inside this museum. It's very casual and a nice walk through if you are nearby. Quite the juxtaposition of modern art in a relatively ancient building. The market is nearby and therefore it's a convenient visit.
A must when you visit Antibes. Fun and wonderful exibition. Helpful and friendly staff, who speak english.

Not even a third of the art is Picasso's. I do not understand the concept of this collection. Its just a meqgre collection in a phantastic building. All in all it has been a great experience. Less because of Picasso, but because of the rest.
Picasso's works has been in the museums all over the world but this place emphasis' his other collections, drawings and mostly sketches. Nice location of the building.

interesting collection and one which is on original mural done on the wall directly . It is fascinating to see the different style of art the Picasso painted over the years. The terrace is garnished of art from various sculptors and one is by Miro .

For us the best part was the excellent account on video (with English subtitles) on the first floor of the Picasso Museum of David Douglas Duncan the photographer who spent time in the late 1950s photographing Picasso and Jacqueline. We often go to museums and art galleries
The location is breathtaking. The exhibits are amazing. The grounds outside are picturesque. This is a beautiful place to visit with family or friends.

Great location. The exibits are not his most popular works, but still very nice tour. It is nice for a couple of hors activity away from the beach.
A nice museum in a beautiful setting, a little smaller than I expected. Nonetheless real character to the building and in a stunning location. Worth a couple of hours out of the sun.
We stayed here for about one hour and it was enough. Their wasn't so many paintings that Picasso had made and overall it was kinda small. Great view from the balcony though!
The muse Picasso , is located in old Antibes , it was an enjoyable visit , this place could be better if they maintain it in a better way

I'm not an art guy, but this held my interest for the 1.5 hours we walked around. Building is cool, views are great, and it's always fun to learn a bit of art history. Antibes was one of my fav stops in this region.

This place will be a disappointment if you are a Picasso fan, as there are only a view average pieces on display with the biggest collection being in Paris, but the views of the Mediterranean are sublime and the Grimaldi palace is architecturally very interesting. Worth a visit

Yes this museum is small, but the building and view itself is worth the stop. Art is very accessible and docents are helpful. The sculptures on the property are inspiring. For the price of a beer this is a real bargain!

My friend and I popped in here before going to the beach and while there were a handful of pieces that we loved, there's a lot of dross in here. It's only 6€, so worth visiting if you're at a loose end, but I wouldn't call it unmissable.

To see Picasso's work in the location where it was painted and with picrures of him at work puts the particular works in context. A rarity. Definitely not to be missed when visiting Antibes. The sculptures were also interesting both inside and outside the museum.
Some great paintings from one period of Picasso's life , well worth seeing along with his ceramics. Resonable collection of some extra artwork as well.

I was not very happy with this museum. The first floor houses the museum shops. The second floor houses an changing exhibit of another artist. The top floor houses the Picasso works which is two rooms. The first room is a series of dozens of pottery plates and a one big Picasso

This museum features two other artists in addition to Picasso. There are two walls of platters which are very interesting. Lots of sketches and photos chronicalling his work but not as many major pieces as I expected to see.
A nice walk through a well curated museum housing some nice art work and a wall of ceramic plates by the master. The balcony has nice views of the bay in Antibes.

Wondering through the quaint town, strolling along the marina and back up the hill on top of the sea wall you can't miss the on this list of things to do in Antibes, the Picasso museum. Not the most impressive collection but the building itself and the views from the terrace

This place has so much potential but it is unrealised. Picasso actually lived in Antibes but there is no real background given to his life here and the Picasso works on show were disappointing.

Picasso collection quite small but included showcases of his atellier. The first three floors were dedicated to a visiting colection of works by Pierre Salouge - odd to my taste. Painted with a paint brush - huge slashes of black and brown on canvas - very monotonous.

My wife loved the museum. Let's say I loved the location of the museum over looking the water the best. Unfortunately there weren't headsets that might have given some insight into the painting. Situated just outside the old town , there in public parking available underground

Not exactly an art lover myself, I went with very low expectations to a gallery of an artist known for being pretty rubbish at art! I kind of saw what I expected. For €6 each we walked around in wonderment at the child-like paintings by Picasso and some other cubist painters.

There is a good collection of Picasso's work here; there is also for from other artists too. The views from the terrace are stunning and there is more art outside. It was great to make the acquaintance of Picasscat who obviously lives there too! Good bookshop, clean bathrooms,

Very fine exhibition of one of Picassos fruitful periods . he lived there for many years and donated a lot of his paintings / drawings and sculptures . to top it off the Museum is situated in an interesting castle at the sea with tremendous fews

Musée Grimaldi is, first of all, an increbile place, ancient and imponent, it certainly has a great atmosphere. The museum itself is pretty cool, lots of works by one of the world's greatest. Prices are very reasonable, and the view from the balcony is astonishing. Totally worth
Fantastic building, setting and art! Great price too at only 6 euros pp. would visit again and recommend, well worth a visit.

This museum is set up on a cliffside with the most breathtaking views. Then you go into the museum and the building is gorgeous. The Picasso works themselves are limited and more from his early works. I loved it but it is not the place to see typical Picasso.
This museum is worth visiting for it's beautiful garden and setting as much as the excellent collection of Picasso's ceramics and lesser number of drawings and paintings.
They exhibition every scrap of Picasso they could find, but none of it is a highlight. Poor explanations. Expensive for what you get. Not much to see. Photographs are not allowed.

My daughters and myself were looking forward to this. Lighting and display of the photography was poor. Too difficult to see. The collection is not exciting to me. The building is more interesting. Beautiful and on the water in ancient Antibes. It was a stones throw from where

This museum is as impressive for the artwork inside, as the views of the Mediterranean Sea from the outside. The castle is amazing to look at inside and out. It is interesting to see the sketches of Picasso and his lesser known works. And you can do it all in less than 1 hour.
this is such a lovely place, really clean, nicely done in a nice architectural building. the collection in the museum is amazing

The Picasso museum is a lovely little museum. It does not take long at all to go through it, and if you are walking around in Antibes- it is definitely worth a visit! The walk around the museum is also beautiful and a true must when in the gem that is Antibes. A true beauty spot.
Wonderful little museum with a very nice collection worth visiting. Beautiful setting. Has a permanent collection as well as traveling exhibits of other artists.

First, Antibes is a gem of a sea side village, a break from the hustle and bustle of Nice. A short ride via train, an easy stroll to the port, a beautiful walk along the coast to the museum, and you are there. Of particular note is Picasso's "Joie de Vivre", but equally

This was a great little find in Antibes.A few euros to enter and something to admire from everyone .A great guitar display and great views of the beautiful coast

Not just Picasso. The building was interesting but other artists featured were not so nice. A lot of the Picasso collection was sketches so don't go expecting loads of famous paintings. He was actually only there for two months inn1946.

Well, the museum does not offer the best paintings of Pablo Picasso, even he lived here. There is only one popular painting, and the others are sketches and photos od Pablo. But anyway, for the good view, you can enjoy everything.

Worth a visit if you're a Picasso fan - but quite small. Many of the famous Picassos seem to be in London or New York but there are some interesting pieces here and some fabulous black and white photographs. Reasonable value at €6 - really great building with good views.

There are not a lot of "cultural things" to do in Antibes and it's one of them. I don't think it's worth coming solely for that as it's quite a small museum but if you happen to be around, you should pay a visit (and walk around the old town). When we visited they were updating

This museum sits in the Grimaldi castle in the old town of Antibes. It is a wonderful location and well worth the visit if you are coming to the old town. However if you are coming solely to see the museum I would not recommend it as it has a limited number of paintings overall
Loved our morning here, perfect intro in to Picasso time in Antibes. Beautiful gift shop and terrace... Maybe a cafe would finish of the experience

The new Picasso museum deserves to be visited. Nice building, from the ground up to the third floor where the woodwork can be seen. Art collection well enhanced. Two hours there, time has flown... We strongly recommend the visit.
Would highly recommend this museum. Many works and changing displays. Affordable entry charges for young and old. Expand your mind a little in a beautiful building.

The museum is in the delightful old town of Antibes with a wonderful setting overlooking the sea.The grounds have a selection of interesting sculptures,including a Miro.There was an exhibition of paintings by Le Corbusier which made an interesting contrast to the
I love this museum because I love the works of Picasso. The place is small enough to see his works in details and to spend few hours doing so. I also love the view from its terrace.

We visited the French Riviera in Dec 2015 along with my family and spent a good portion of the day at Antibes - As part of Antibes, the Picasso museum was well worth the time. We started the walk around Anitbes and visited many sites including the Picasso museum. The Museum

This is now my favorite of all art museums, nudging the Getty Malibu. It is a small collection, easy to see in a few hours. Admission is cheap. We visited in January, arriving just as they opened. Almost no crowd at all save a group of school kids
Musee picasso is difrent from others museum. Afer new stasr is worth to visit. Buy some things in a shop. Don t miss a good choice of book about painters.
Building amazing as are views. Collection is mostly work done while staying nearby, so not so exciting as other museums with his collections. Was not a first rate collection of Picassos.

Great find. Lots of paintings, pictures and drawings of Corbusier and Picasso. You can see the genius from beginning to finished product.

This was the first time I had the opportunity to see Picasso's work. It was quite fascinating to see the places where he worked and created his art. The museum is quite small but you will easily spend there one hour or even more if you spend a bit more time focusing on the works

If it was good enough for Picasso to live in in 1946, rest assured that this wonderful castle contributes to why you must go to Antibes. Apparently, his rediscovery of colors after the nightmare darkness of WWII was aided by being in this lovely setting. The sculptures and

We stayed in Antibes for two weeks this summer in the old town, just some hundred meter from this great museum. It is worth visiting. Picasso lived here for some important years of his life. You get the story here. And at beautiful sight of the town and the sea.

Facing the ocean, we got unmatched ocean view from this museum, and there are some art works by Picasso in the backyard facing the ocean, it is beautiful!

Got taken here as a child and have been back a few times. One of the best Picasso museums in a stunning location with beautiful outdoor area and some of the best views. I must see, but don,t go on a Monday!
great museum great view, great époque of the arts, will go each year again and again, just difficult to reach by car and to park, otherwise a jewel

Dropped in at this museum on my way back from Cannes to Nice. The museum has many exhibits of Picasso's works-his pictures taken in his atatelier after 1946, paintings, drowings, pottery he painted. From the exhibits, I could feel how he loved this small seaside town and his

The Picasso Museum is not just a museum showcasing Picassos work, but it is a museum that explains Picasso's story through the eyes of a photographer. Very worthwhile! It is located in a beautiful section of Antibe, right on the Mediteranean. The museum contains Picassos
The Picasso museum was a good stop on a rainy day, but the collection is limited in scope and quality. On the other hand, the fee is low, so I guess this is a case of you get what you pay for!

What a treat to see so many different mediums that Picasso used. Seeing paintings on such a large scale and the amount of pottery on display is worth every minute spent in this remarkable museum. Make sure to find your way to the outdoor garden area. Beautiful views from there.

Housed in the old Grimaldi Castle, this museum offers a collection of work during a period when Picasso had escaped the war years in Paris with its grim, iron-grey-German-uniform colour into a burgeoning polychrome that reaches its apogee in ceramics and the joyous dance in "La

We were staying near this museum in Antibes so naturally we heard about it and had to go. We first visited the museum on a rainy Monday however when we got there we found a sign saying it was open everyday except Monday, this was our fault for not researching it more. At the

Excellent collection of Picasso's work housed in an interesting building with terrific views out to sea. Close to the centre of Antibes so can be combined with a visit to the market or old town, or an amble amongst the expensive yachts moored in the nearby marina.
I did not venture in to the museum so cannot comment on this. However, the buildings themselves are wonderful and make great photos

If you visit the old town of Antibes and you like Picasso, do not miss this small Museum. Most of the works are from a short period in 1946. The building itself is very impressive and the sights of the sea are very beautiful.

Free at festival weekends. Shut for lunch so time your visit and busy at afternoon opening time (2pm) so may be better to visit a bit later. Well organised museum with many photos of Picasso plus various art works.

As per title, I went back 3 times, every time finding something more to see, a new piece, a new exhibition. Though Picasso is not my favorite painter, I still appreciate his creativity and the museum portrays it really well in this wonderful building in the heart of old Antibes.

The museum is dedicated to the master, his muse Jacqueline, and their life together. Besides Picasso paintings, I was surprised to see the amazing handmade and painted ceramics in all its beauty and variety. Note that the museum has a siesta break between 12 PM and 2 PM.
A remarkable find! This museum was, for me, so inspiring. The setting is incredible and the opportunity to see art of this nature is life-changing.

Beautiful building where Picasso had his studio, and is now a showplace for many photos & collected works. Amazing view out the window of the sea.

A beautiful Musee in a wonderful setting in the heart of Antibes old town. A disappointing selection of Picasso's work on show at the moment, some must be on loan since I've been here before and seen more, I especially remember there being many more of his ceramics. Interesting

It is worth visiting the museum just for the building and the view from the terrace. The exhibition itself is very interesting and it gives a nice perspective of Picasso's work whilst he was living in Antibes
if you like "art" to just like art it will be great i suppose . visited the museum and found it boring . a 7 year ol could have done the drawings . total waste of time .

It was great to see the exhibition in the place where Picasso created his finest works. Unfortunately most of the information cards next to his works are of small print but with English translation.

Even if you are not a big fan of Picasso this museum is such a great value as the building itself is magnificent standing on a hillside by beautiful Cote d'azur. Not the biggest collection but paintings and ceramics are powerful, whimsical and so Picasso.

The Picasso Museum is a great place to see a great many of the artists lesser know pictures. The museum contains many of his sketches and pottery items, which do not appear in other exhibitions. Well with a visit, when you are in Antibes.
A great small museum in the grimaldi fort . Pictures and ceramics works of Picasso made here in 1946 . Only 3 euros for seniors , great view overlooking the see . Don't miss !
Interesting small museum showing a lot of pictures and only the paintings of the period Picasso painted there. One should not compare this museum to the one in Barcelona or Paris....
A must if you are in Antibes. The ramparts are beautiful as are the views across the bay. Don't miss le Marche Proven can open everyday. X

Difficult to find through the market but on the sea front, most amazing situation overlooking the Cote D'AZURE. sculptures by other artists mix with his paintings, drawings and thought processes in a superb environment.

A splendid museum. A whole bunch of Picasso's in one place in an awesome setting. I'm not qualified to comment on Picasso other than to say the paintings are emblematic of his stay in Antibes and that is why you must go to this museum if you are there.

This is a great little museum with a nice grouping of Picasso's and a few others' works. The setting is marvelous and the building is lovely. You can do it easily in an hour or two. Be sure to enjoy the sculptures outside. Recommended.

Musee Picasso is located in the old city in Antibes on a high promontory that has a fabulous sea view, no doubt an inspiration to Picasso when he lived and worked there in 1946-47 time period. This is where his famous painting, Joie de Vivre, is displayed. Also, his famous
Probably wasted on a philistine such as me, but meaningful to the cognoscenti. I love much of Picasso's art but I'd rather buy a book.

Antibes is a lovely town to visit. If you love Picasso it's interesting to see his paintings at this little museum.

A wonderful castle with great Picasso overlooking the water in Antibes! The outdoor sculpture garden overlooking the water is spectacular! The French government let Picasso live here on condition that he leave the art he created here, and I suspect it was a great deal for both!

The Picasso Museum is just amazing. The museum itself is pretty incredible, so much to see. The town of Antibes is very interesting to tour, so many little curving streets. The outdoor market is well worth the visit, so many olives! The harbor has a lot of beautiful yachts

My girlfriend is an artist and she was in love with this small but beautiful museum which featured some of Picasso's work along with one other local artist. The castle itself is interesting and the view over the bay is stunning.

The Picasso paintings are on the second floor and are amazing. The best part to me was that the museum made Picasso the man come alive with personal history. The surrounding landscape of the Musee gives breathtaking views of the Cote d Azure. This musee is well worth

This is a smallish museum where one floor of the museum is dedicated to Picasso, a one time resident who donated some works to the city. There is some interesting photographs from the period, and quite a number of his drawings as well. The terrace has several sculptures as

Its a picasso museum but you can always go the the louve or the museum de orsay to see some of his paintings. The number of paintings in this museum is not that much. I suggest you go around the Marais area and enjoy the place and restaurants around it.

What am amazing setting to see beautiful art! The first floor is given to other artists, most of whom lived or worked in Antibes. The works of Picasso are exhibited on the second floor and are well with a visit. The sculpture garden at the end of the visit is superb and we

The Picasso works were wonderful and I felt that I left with a better understanding of the artist. However vast space is given to other artists hence my four star rating. It's in a great building, worth the walk!

The beautiful Grimaldi castle host the Picasso Museum, in the old city of Antibes. You can easily reach it by foot from the train station through the vieil Antibes (15 min). Close to plage de la Gravette (7 min by foot) on the left and to plage du Ponteil on the right (10-15 min

We had a day visit to here whilst in Nice and popped in to the museum. excellent collection. Good introduction in English to Picasso and his involvement in the area. Some interesting pieces of work with good explanations. I really enjoyed the ceramics. Worth a visit.
Wondeful, as ever, to see some pieces I've mostly seen on posters etc. Lovely buildong (chateau) which lets the light in, in all the right places.

It is a very interesting place in Antibes. In addition to the work by Picasso, the museum also featuring the work from many other artists about the same time of Picasso. It looks like this is the time and place that Picasso transformed into the Picasso we mostly know today.

This museum has some nice pieces and some strange ones I have never seen before. It does not hold a candle to the one in Paris that is STILL under renovations. But will do when the other is not available.
The museum is great and you can see the beautiful paints of Picaso and other arts. I really recommend the visit in the Old Town of Antibes. The view is stuning!

due to the fact that you can see Picasso works frequently, we were particularly pleased to find a small but nice selection of Nicolas de Staël works .. the castle is situated in the old town of Antibes and offers a great view over the bay and the snow-topped Alpes from its

Lovely building, not the greatest museum but an insinght into the artist's work. The town of Antibes however is wonderful, something for everyone if you like boats this is the place to go, one of the largest marinas in Europe. A great place to capture the light that draws so

The views around here are stunning! We visited, but did not have enough time to visit the museum itself. There are wonderful places to eat around here, and a fantastic fresh food market as well. Note the market closes a little early, so make sure to get there on time. I have
It is not all Picasso and the building itself is lovely. Worth a visit if you have time, but an hour is probably long enough.

The building itself is beautiful. Decent collection of Picasso works. Works by other artists are a mixed bag. Interpretation of the art could be better. A nice way to spend an hour if you have it, but strolling around beautiful Antibes may be more enjoyable.

Its no Barcelona Museum but it is a nice insight into the work he did while he was living in Antibes! The building is beautiful and the views are stunning!! Think it was bout 6euros. Check opening hours before you make the mission

A lovely small museum, including some original Picasso works. There are also works of other artists. It was free to enter, but there should be no photos allowed. I do not appreciate a lot a what Picasso produced, although I have been to many collections of his work, but I

Lovely to visit a location where Picasso produced many of his artwork. Museum has many of Picasso's original (and even unfinished work) and pieces donated by his daughter Jacqueline Picasso. Would probably recommend 1-2 hours here, but only if you've seen much of Antibes
I like the view from terrace, the museum itself is less interesting than I expected. Picasso lived in this house for 4 month, and museum has his work for this period.
The sculpture garden is small but very enjoyable. View is terrific. Building is wonderful. Very limited hours. Half of the building noises a contemporary selection, not Picasso.

Here is an example of 'The kings new cloths'; really poor work perporting to be art. In and out of this exhibition within 20 minutes. In fact the location and architecture of the gallery is more interesting and more artistically rewarding than the wall hangings. At 6 euro each

Not a huge fan of Picasso but those who are will love this museum for the art and biographical info. Non-fans will like the historic building and the fabulous views. And it's only a short walk to the nearest cafe for a refresher afterwards.

The museum itself is very interesting because it's located next to the sea; it was once a medieval fortress. There are many paintings paying homage to Picasso. His works can be found near the end of your exploration of the museum. The cost of entry is relatively inexpensive
